sentence: Salesforce (CRM) has taken the cloud computing industry by storm and shows no signs of slowing down, offering investors exposure to one of the best companies in a fast-growing sector.
Salesforce provides sales leads marketing, customer service, and technical support in on-demand software.
Following its fiscal first quarter earnings, Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brendan Barnicle raised his price target to $80, noting that the company is exceeding expectations on all fronts.
"Despite FX headwind of $175 million to $200 million, Salesforce.com raised guidance across all metrics," Barnicle wrote in a note.
"Based on the continued billings and transaction momentum, we are raising estimates."

"Salesforce has surpassed the $6 billion annual revenue run rate faster than any other enterprise software company, and our current outlook puts us on track to reach a $7 billion revenue run rate later this year," CEO Marc Benioff said in a statement.
"Our goal is to be the fastest to reach $10 billion in annual revenue."
As a cloud computing company, billings is often a better metric then revenue, because it focuses on customers acquired.
In the quarter, billings grew 21% year over year, as opposed to expectations of 13%, Barnicle noted.
This was especially impressive, as the company faced "seasonality headwinds," according to the company.
In the first quarter, Salesforce earned an adjusted 16 cents a share on $1.151 billion in revenue.
Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters were expecting earnings of an adjusted 14 cents a share on $1.5 billion in revenue.
For the second quarter, Salesforce expects to earn between 17 cents and 18 cents a share, with revenue between $1.59 billion and $1.6 billion.

Even as Salesforce gets bigger, approaching that $10 billion revenue figure, the company believes it can improve even more, despite having what Barnicle called "one of its cleanest quarters on record."
On the earnings call, management said it could reach operating margins around the 30% level, up significantly from where they are today.
That implies that Salesforce is getting smarter about its expenses, leaving more money to flow to cash flow from operations, which totaled $730.9 million at the end of the first quarter.
With billings showing no signs of slowing down, more cash for shareholders and a fast growing sector, Salesforce.com may be right for investors portfolios.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
